DOC.HEAD: L.A. Approves Mandatory Recycling of Household Trash
Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The City Council has unanimously approved mandatory trash separation and recycling in a $160 million program to cut in half the amount of garbage deposited in the city's rapidly filling landfills. While about 1,000 U.S. cities have some kind of recycling program, the Los Angeles effort will be among the nation's largest, along with those in New York City and statewide in New Jersey. Mayor Tom Bradley said he will sign the measure approved Wednesday. ``The era of the disposable society, when cans and papers can be carelessly tossed aside, is coming to an end,'' he said. ``Through this plan, the city now establishes a `no-excuses-accepted' policy when it comes to recycling.'' The plan will require all 720,000 single-family households in the city to separate glass and plastic bottles, aluminum cans and newspaper into different containers for collection. The city eventually will sell reusable materials to recyclers. The program is to be phased in over three years, with the first neighborhoods required to participate by next September. The $160 million is a three-year estimate. It has not been determined whether the city or homeowners will pay for the hundreds of thousands of bins and cans needed. It also has not been decided how the program will be enforced. Also Wednesday, the council began considering a proposal to force private trash haulers to recycle. Private haulers collect garbage from businesses and larger apartment buildings, which account for about two-thirds of all waste in the city.
